openstack/python-keystone/centos/meta_pa.message: Shouldn't you be re-creating these patch files? It looks like you are just editing them?

It seems wrong to me to keep the old author, dates, etc... and more error prone if you are combining parts of the old and new patch. But if that is the recommended approach then I will accept it. I would be curious to hear opinions from Saul, Jim, Scott and Chris.
So you are saying that you cut and pasted parts of the new patch into the old one? If so, please don't do that. You should be pushing the new patch with updated headers and everything.

I don't have much of a problem with it if the patch is mostly the same and the intent is the same.  But at a bare minimum, if you change a patch other than just refreshing context ie. hunk offsets, you must sign it.  I don't see a signed-off-by line here, even one from the original author.  Weren't reviewers enforcing this last year?  No sign off means not ready for production.
Patch file itself is regenerated, then I use meld tool just pick the "must have" part, so you could focus on the real change part when review. :)

I could do so. But I still prefer current way to use meld to compare and copy the patch. This method is shared by Scott Little to me, and I like it due to it keep the patch seem clean. 
If patch is not edited correctly, it should lead to build issue for most cases.
Could you share me what is harmful with current method?

Get the dashes out of the shortlog.  "git log --oneline" must show a proper description, not some string polluted with dashes.  Also where is your signed-off-by line since you made changes to this?  Always use "git commit -s" when you're making a commit for production.  It's a good habit to get into to always use -s anyway.

mtce-common/src/common/msgClass.cpp.message: Don't mention the specific number of bytes.

There should never have been truncation. There is no bug here. MAX_CHARS_HOSTNAME is set to 256 characters while a host name can only be 64 in Linux. We actually limit the max hostname size to 50 to account for the cluster name being added to it.

This change is driven by analysis tool warning.

Totally agree with you, Eric.
And this fix is just to avoid the compile error.
So do you prefer to update the comments like below?
"
buffer is expanded for CLUSTER_HOST_SUFFIX, to avoid the gcc-8.2.1 report theoretical string truncation issue.
"
Thanks.

This is not needed. Consider DOS log flooding. 

Suggest

UNUSED(ret)
Hi Eric, sorry. You are right. Let me correct it.

Cannot use UNUSED(ret), gcc will still report compile error with it.
And there should be no flooding, since the log is only for real truncation case.

Hi Eric, the return value is "the number of characters excluding null terminator", so it should be "sizeof(iface_hostname) - 1" or less. If return value is sizeof(iface_hostname), it means there is no null terminator in the output buffer, and truncation is needed. 
Here is the man for snprintf return value:
"
RETURN VALUE
       Upon successful return, these functions return the number of characters printed (excluding the null byte used to end output to strings).

       The functions snprintf() and vsnprintf() do not write more than size bytes (including the terminating null byte ('\0')).  If the output was truncated due to this limit, then
       the return value is the number of characters (excluding the terminating null byte) which would have been written to the final string if  enough  space  had  been  available.
       Thus, a return value of size or more means that the output was truncated.  (See also below under NOTES.)

"
Redundant. snprintf already handles adding a null terminator.
snprintf will always add the null terminator.
For truncation case, snprintf will not add the null terminator.

gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drive.message: so we don't need to do current[cisco_apic.DIST_NAMES] & current[cisco_apic.SYNC_STATE] anymore?
Correct. The l3_db create_router code calls _make_router_dict after the transaction has committed, and this includes our extension attributes.
This used to be part of the transaction but now its not. Is this intended?
Yes - _rebuild_host_path_for_network must be called outside any transaction because it might need to create SVI ports, but it manages local transactions where needed.
instead of using result[0], result[1] or result[2], you can just use snat_ip, gateway_ip, cidr directly.
Good point - or I could just remove line 4118.
Not sure if I understand the comment here regarding "that relevant AIM state has changed". Which AIM state we are talking about here?

This refers to the host link stuff changing, either manually (via aimctl) or via LLDP-triggered RPCs such as update_link. If there are a rapid series of updates affecting the same port, this code will run on the last update of the series and find the SVI port, so we might get this warning logged during an intermediate update, but should have no real harm done. I can clarify the comment a bit.
Is there a reason why you didn't use payload.desired_state here?
Yes - The desired_state is a router_db object, which does not have our extension attributes that are needed below.

Since we're dependent on where calls in upstream neutron are made, should we add a NOTE: or something here, indicating that if upstream neutron adds or removes publishers of this event, that there may need to be changes here accordingly? I guess you could argue that as long as we have the required arguments then it's okay - just worried that we're special-casing this for one upstream publisher in neutron.

The same would apply to all callbacks - upstream changing where they are called or what args are passed could break our code. I purposely did not add **kwargs to our callback methods to make sure we would notice if the args are changed upstream so we could make any needed corresponding changes.

Since this callback is somewhat unique in being called in multiple places, I tried to include plenty of details in the comments. The code on lines 2488-2492 helps ensure that we are only processing the call we want. Calling it from other places would not be a problem unless the orig_binding and new_binding args were passed, and these showed that the port had just become bound, which would be very unlikely from anywhere other than _commit_port_binding.

The need to look for data on the stack is described in the comment. I agree there is risk of the function or variable names changing upstream, but I'm not sure what additional information would be useful. The UTs would definitely break if an upstream change prevented the bind_context from being found.

Do you feel adding an additional comment would help? Or maybe adding "NOTE: " to the beginning of the comment before this method?
I don't think it's worth a respin at this point. If you do need to make additional changes, maybe just add the "NOTE:', otherwise we can keep it.
The code in rpc.py had a REVISIT to possibly include retries for this method, in order to avoid retrying the entire RPC. Are we confident now that we no longer need to add one here?

I think so. The transaction starting on line 4106 below is a read-only transaction, so should not result in any StaleDataError or other retry-able exceptions due to conflicts with concurrent write transactions. The create_port call on line 4182 does a write transaction, but the ML2Plus plugin's create_port method has its own retry decorator, and that decorator should do its job now that it is no longer being called inside an active transaction.

gbpservice/neutron/services/apic_aim/l3_.message: So we removed the top level transaction here and used individual smaller read/write transactions across this file. What's the pros and cons of this approach?

I will submit a follow-on patch that moves much of this code from the L3 plugin to callbacks in the MD. I initially didn't include that here, in case this patch needed back-porting to releases prior to queens.

The main pro is that we no longer call the upstream implementation of create_floatingip, which is a non-get REST API, from within transaction, and therefore don't need to worry about hitting any transaction guards anywhere inside the upstream code.

Its also a step towards eliminating the need for our own L3 plugin, which is one of Mandeep's long-term goals. Most of what we need to do in the L3 plugin can eventually be done through callbacks, at least in recent releases, except for the iterating over non SNAT host pool subnets.

I don't see any major cons, especially once we move what we can to PRECOMMIT callbacks, which will be within the existing transactions in the upstream code.

deployment/tripleo-firewall/tripleo-fire.message:

doc/source/specs/ussuri/flexible-reserva.message: How does the operator change their custom policies? It should be in scope of this spec but I'm not sure if it Is already written in this proposed spec.
I think this became more clear later, but the policies are changed by the operator changing the code or configuration of their externally-provided policy service.

So, I guess you assumed the proposed usage service could *NOT* access to the blazar DB. Is that right? If so, I think this can be implemented out of Blazar project.
IOW, I could not get what is the proposed change to Blazar from this spec.

[later]
Ah, I think I got it. You are going to have your own usage service completely *EXTERNALLY* deployed so that the blazar's change would be only several changes to call that usage service. So the proposed three APIs are not for blazar itself but for the usage service. And that usage service has several interface for operators to change the custom policies which is not written in the spec, right?

However, I don't think we want every operator who use Blazar to develop such a usage service, so I think it is better to implement the proposed checks within Blazar without external service and instead we can change Blazar to have additional APIs to get operators' custom policies, no?

> 1. The types of policies can be incredibly varied and are difficult
 > to model generically. 

Right, then I would take the second alternative. See below.

> Ah, I think I got it. You are going to have your own usage service
 > completely *EXTERNALLY* deployed so that the blazar's change would
 > be only several changes to call that usage service. So the proposed
 > three APIs are not for blazar itself but for the usage service. And
 > that usage service has several interface for operators to change
 > the custom policies which is not written in the spec, right?

Yes, exactly. The interface for the operator to change their custom policies is left unspecified as it is the operator's decision. It could be as simple as hard-coding in a service or as complex as building a full UI that allows another employee to manage. This also allows integration against existing external services, e.g. an HPC allocation tracker.

 > However, I don't think we want every operator who use Blazar to
 > develop such a usage service, so I think it is better to implement
 > the proposed checks within Blazar without external service and
 > instead we can change Blazar to have additional APIs to get
 > operators' custom policies, no?

What form do the policies take in this scenario? We initially discussed such an idea and it is presented later in the spec as an alternative, though perhaps without much elaboration.

I agree that requiring the development of such a service puts additional implementation burden on operators. That's why I think a future spec should be created to develop an example/default implementation of this service that can be deployed alongside (or within) Blazar. However, I think ultimately supporting an external service is the right choice for a few reasons:

1. The types of policies can be incredibly varied and are difficult to model generically. Consider policies around # of simultaneous reservations allowed, or # of simultaneous nodes allowed, or maybe some users are allowed to reserve from a specific IP range but others are not. Then there are limits on reservation length or under what circumstances a lease can be prolonged. We have implemented most of the above at some point as part of our efforts to manage demand for resources on our cloud (via patches to Blazar and more "hacky" solutions where leases are "reaped" after they are created). There are likely other scenarios that would be useful or obvious to other operators, which are not yet obvious to us.

2. External services are already used in many HPC centers. Central accounting is a pattern in use by e.g., European Grid Infrastructure (EGI) and XSEDE/Jetstream. Central accounting is important because there may be multiple OpenStack clouds that can be used by a single user/project, but there is one budget that applies to them all. In this case, a policy should not be managed solely by a single Blazar deployment, as it doesn't have the "full picture."

If the usage service is meant to be shared by multiple Blazar deployments, whether from the same cloud (in different regions) or from multiple clouds, there should be some way to identify where the request came from.

I would include region_name and some way to identify the cloud, maybe via its auth_url.

Nit: I would call this and the state key:

current_state / requested_state

I think this is only the case when you implement this out of the Blazar master branch, isn't it? As long as this is in Blazar's master, we take care not to break the interface and points to take care is just the format of contents of passed arguments (reservation/lease dictionary) and in this aspect the service/plugin update is necessary regardless of whether the interface is RESTful (service) or a function (plugin). I even  think changing the REST API needs more work than function-API change.

And another reason why I'm reluctant is it results in database duplication between the usage and blazar service, which would lead to a lot of codes to avoid inconsistency and would be bugbear.

Thoughts?

> TL; DR: I think the discussion for service or plugin topic needs
 > more opinion from other reviewers.

Having implemented the plugin approach before for Chameleon, I lean towards the service approach. I believe it will provide a better separation of concerns and make it easier to deploy Blazar (no need to ship extra code).

One middle ground could be to have calls to the external service implemented as a plugin. This way it would be possible to override it with a custom plugin if that is what operators want to do.

> Totally agreed with this. But if it doesn't have a database, I
 > don't get why such "POST /v1/on-end" API is needed. I thought this
 > is needed just to update and synchronize the usage database with
 > Blazar's. Maybe I'm missing something... I'd like this spec to
 > clear which part of usage service part and blazar part it describes
 > so that I can see what is necessary for community and what is
 > necessary for operators.

The external service may be tracking some other information, for example the credit balance of each project. As mentioned elsewhere in the spec, if each reservation takes away credit from the balance, an early end would need to refund the unused credits.

TL; DR: I think the discussion for service or plugin topic needs more opinion from other reviewers.

 > Each major release would require rebasing or cherry-picking any commits that touch the usage enforcement layer. 

As long as it is designed as a plugin with a clear interface, this efforts can be kept small. On the other hand, with the usage service architecture, the json scheme for the new usage service, e.g. for /v1/check-update API, should catch up with a new scheme when new features (query parameters) are added to Blazar. This means we need to take care of (IOW: document, test and review) the REST API of the usage service as well as Blazar's REST API every time we add a feature into Blazar.

 > Any function/module could be imported and referenced, meaning future changes to unrelated Blazar functionality can break enforcement. 

Any function/module could be imported and referenced, letting operators easily catch up with new features. What we need is to have CI tests not to break the enforcement. Having another service makes it more difficult to test and debug the failure that happens in the Zuul gate.

 > it could pause execution if implemented poorly

I think this is a bug to be fixed. As long as we use that usage check and the usage check fails due to unknown issue, fail first is the right thing to do. If operators don't think so and if it is plugin-designed, they can just use another thread to execute the check since it is up to operators.

 > it's unnecessary/bad design to store anything Blazar already is tracking.

Totally agreed with this. But if it doesn't have a database, I don't get why such "POST /v1/on-end" API is needed. I thought this is needed just to update and synchronize the usage database with Blazar's. Maybe I'm missing something... I'd like this spec to clear which part of usage service part and blazar part it describes so that I can see what is necessary for community and what is necessary for operators.

Additional effort is needed mostly in regards to packaging and maintaining forks. Each major release would require rebasing or cherry-picking any commits that touch the usage enforcement layer. Over time, the operators may be making many changes to that layer, with each atomic commit adding more maintenance burden. This is itself another kind of a bugbear.

There are other drawbacks to this approach. For one, I would argue that it makes it too easy for implementors of the enforcement layer to break Blazar's abstraction layer. Any function/module could be imported and referenced, meaning future changes to unrelated Blazar functionality can break enforcement. For this reason I typically am in favor of abstracting at the level of published HTTP-based interfaces.

Another consideration is availability. Even if the enforcement layer does not raise exceptions (which we can deal with in Blazar logic), it could pause execution if implemented poorly, such as waiting for a very long time for some sort of response from an external service. If the enforcement layer is itself a separate HTTP service, Blazar has the ability to easily set timeouts and deal with errors (such as allowing the request, as controlled by ``allow_on_error``). It is more difficult to enforce such time-related constraints when the logic is internal to Blazar via custom patches we don't have control over.

I am personally not concerned about database duplication, because I don't see any reason why any data would need to be stored by the enforcement layer and would argue it's unnecessary/bad design to store anything Blazar already is tracking. Blazar will send as much relevant information as possible to the enforcement service so that it is not necessary to store state. If the enforcement layer wants to pull additional state from Blazar, such as the other pending leases owned by the user, it can call Blazar itself using the user's token.

Maintaining another service is not a design decision I take lightly. There are obvious trade-offs but I think they are the right trade-offs in this use-case. I would be open to an approach where we load a usage extension via stevedore and require operators implement their code as a Python module. This still means that things like service timeouts in the extension layer can cause denial of availability to Blazar, and implementors can still import Blazar functions/modules, but at least they don't have to maintain custom patches to provide the enforcement capability.

I suggest adding as reference the specs for Nova vendordata2, which uses a similar approach.

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/newton/implemented/vendordata-reboot.html
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/ocata/implemented/vendordata-reboot-ocata.html
To be more precise, a lease which is rejected doesn't get created in the database at all. Can be fixed in a follow-up patch.

specs/train/redundancy.rst.message:
We have option to support multi-vnffg as in [1], so how it differ?

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/tacker/blob/master/samples/tosca-templates/vnffg-nsd/tosca-multiple-vnffg-nsd.yaml

specs/ussuri/Redundancy-module-for-VNFFG.message: What does this mean? Is it possible to heal or scale a VNFFG instance for now?
There are approved blueprints for auto-healing / scaling project in tacker. The code development of them are not completed, so we can't test them.
AFAIK, Tacker doesn't support VNFFG healing and VNFFG scaling so you should rephrase this correctly.

Why do you want a new option of tacker-client? I think you can create a second VNFFG by including two VNFFG definition in your VNFFGD. Alternatively you can have two VNFFG by just creating the VNFFG twice.

Of course, definition of two VNFFGs in VNFFGD or creating VNFFG twice can be alternatives of our proposal. However, there is no definition for specific VNFD instance in VNFFG, so two VNFFGs can have same paths(same VNF instance, same VL). To address this, we will add a function when selecting VNF instance in second VNFFG to exclude the selected VNF instance in first VNFFG from the VNF instance set if possible. Then, two VNFFGs will be disjointed as much as possible. To do this, we think adding a new api in tacker-client is better solution.

IMO, it's better to have a new parameter indicating redundant VNFFG in VNFFGD like VDU anti-affinity policy [1]. If doing like your proposal, there are inconsistency between VNFFGD and actually created resources as VNFFGD specify only 1 VNFFG but Tacker creates two.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/563844/5/specs/rocky/vdu-affinity-policy.rst
Thank you for your comment. I also think it's better idea to put parameter indicating redundant VNFFG in VNFFGD. We decide to accept the method.

Does it performs manually? How it choose the VNF? 

Can I get more explanation?

Currently, when tacker creates VNFFGs through VNFFGD, VNF instances that consist of VNFFG are randomly selected among the already-made VNF instances. Therefore, when we create the multiple VNFFGs with the same VNFFGD, same VNF instances can be chosen in high probability. 

For example, There are 4 VNF instances (VNF1, VNF1', VNF2, VNF2') and two instances (VNF1, VNF1')  are made from VNFD 1 and the other two VNF instances (VNF2, VNF2') are created from VNFD2. Also, there is one VNFFGD that describes VNFFG have to consist of VNFD1 and VNFD2 as below.


VNFD1 => VNF1, VNF1'
VNFD2 => VNF2, VNF2'

VNFFGD => VNFD1 -> VNFD2
-----------------------------------------------------------

In this case, when we create two VNFFGs (VNFFG1, VNFFG2) using command at twice, same VNF instances can be chosen because tacker choose VNF instances that construct VNFFG randomly.

Like, VNF1 and VNF2 are chosen for VNFFG1 
and VNF1 and VNF2' are chosen for VNFFG2. 

As a result, VNF1 is multi-chosen in this situation.

          - - - - 
VNFFG1 => l VNF1 l -> VNF2
          - - - - 

          - - - - 
VNFFG2 => l VNF1 l -> VNF2'
          - - - - 
-----------------------------------------------------------

So we want to propose new option, which can choose VNF instances that are not chosen in VNFFG as much as possible when we make VNFFG. 

In other words, As VNF1 and VNF2 are chosen for VNFFG1,when we create the other VNFFG, VNF1 and VNF2 are excluded. So, VNF1' and VNF2' are chosen for VNFFG2. 

-----------------------------------------------------------
VNFFG1 =>  VNF1'  -> VNF2
          

VNFFG2 =>  VNF1  -> VNF2'
-----------------------------------------------------------

In other words, We want to create multiple VNFFGs that don't have redundant instances as much a possible.
If you make changes to tacker-client, I think you have to make changes to API.
Yes. We plan to modify api in tacker-client to provide option for redundancy.
I meant tacker-API, not tackerclient. You need a API parameter to pass the new option of tackerclient to tacker-server.

When we talked about this in IRC, I thought I suggested a course of looking up the resource providers and their allocations and then from the allocation consumers (we could filter out the ones that don't have VCPU/MEMORY_MB since those wouldn't be nova allocations), we then need to determine if:

nova/cmd/manage.py.message: This is what I said in the commit message and below.

I'm not sure how much we care about performance in an audit command. Paging support in placement when listing resource providers could be nice in general though and might be something we could add later as a TODO.

In some recent tests getting 10,000 allocation candidates (which is more expensive (by a _lot_) than getting a list of resource providers) took about 17 seconds.

Until we're exploring UIs that need to list unfiltered resource providers, I don't think we have a clear use case for server-side pagination.

Or to put it another way: if you need fewer resource providers, ask a better question (make a better query).

As I've said elsewhere, we could have leaked migration-based allocations for end-state migrations, e.g. migrations that are in 'error' status. You wouldn't catch those here. This is another reason why I think we should be starting from what placement thinks is correct and working backward to verify in the nova database.
I agree that what Matt says is the right order or processing.

Aren't these really the only two we care about as far as identifying if it's nova-owned resources? Some instances won't have DISK_GB (volume-backed) or VGPU, but most/all would have VCPU/MEMORY_MB (well maybe VGPU allocations won't include VCPU? I'm not sure - depends on how that admin setup the flavor).
I can make it a parameter for admins which want to check specific resource classes and just check by default VCPU and MEMORY_MB

As I mentioned in the commit message, I don't think going from the compute nodes is maybe the best way. For example, let's say the admin deleted a nova-compute service which leaked the resource provider because it still had migration-based allocations on it [1]. The nova-compute service restarted (or wasn't stopped and the update_available_resource periodic ran and created a new resource provider for a new compute node record with a new uuid). In that case we could still have allocations against an orphaned old resource provider which no longer has a compute node - although in fairness that likely might not hurt scheduling because placement could return that resource provider but the scheduler would filter it out b/c there wouldn't be a compute node for it. That's not the end of the world, but it does mean there are orphaned things in placement which do potentially affect scheduling (especially if you configure the scheduler and set max_placement_results low like CERN does).

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-June/007097.html

When you bool a requests.Response is runs 'self.ok' which translates to status_code < 400. So unless ksa has done some jiggery pokery with that interface (which would be horrible) this will raise ConnectFailure on a 404.

Also, you'll never get a 404 from GET /resource_providers because it is a collection resources. Instead you'll get a response like:

    GET http://ds1:8000/resource_providers?uuid=$(uuidgen)
    {"resource_providers": []}

So you'll either need to check the length of the resource_providers attribute in the response, or, when getting a single resource provider, actually GET it: GET /resource_providers/{uuid} , not filter by uuid.

I really wouldn't worry about that. Placement can return several thousand resource providers in well under a second and the volume of data is fairly small, especially when considering that it will be thrown away after the command line finishes.

_skeleton_role_/tasks/main.yml.j2.message: this will load all variable files found in the vars path. Making it possible that one var which meets the current criteria will overwrite another in a different file should the variable pattern match. In terms of operating system specific variables only one file should be loaded when found. Other var files can be loaded within the role using task logic as required.

I'm not sure the bug you mentioned is something we'd experience. The with_first_round for operating system related variable files is something that we've been using for years so I'm positive there are no issues with it.

In terms of variable mashing, I'm sure there are plenty of places where this works just fine, however, its something that can be misused, and I'd like to ensure we're not introducing a new foot-gun. If we're loading shadow variables, we should set a default in defaults/main.yml and load OS specific variables in vars/<<OS-FILE>>. Then its clear that an option can be overridden by the user but otherwise OS defined.

I believe we may be overthinking how many files we'll have per-OS. I could see us redefining things a couple times for something like RHEL7,8 maybe Fedora28,30,etc, but in most cases these values will all be the same, and having clear OS specific values, even if they're repeated is better than having obscure, or otherwise, assumed values. My general mantra is that Ansible is NOT a programming language and should not be treated as such. We should always strive to be DRY, however, its not practical in Ansible and I believe creating this pattern at scale will cause more problems than its worth.

Are you aware of a bug regarding location looked because documentation is very clear regarding where it loads stuff from when run inside the role: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/include_vars_module.html

I already used this pattern in multiple places and did not spot any misbehavors.

The overlay loading is by desig: intended behavior as it allows to define values in minimal number of places.

The precedence order of the files is key here, the most specific ones are loaded last because if a variable is defined in multiple places the value that will win is the one in the most specific place.

We do want to avoid the case where adding a new variable that applies to all redhat distributions would need to be added identically to 10-15 files.

A variable should be defined only at the place where it diverges from its parent. It like inheritance.

Done

I was reading the 2.62 microversion changes for event field at L59 and thinking do we need this new policy ? 

We are already providing the host info based on existing policy BASE_POLICY_NAME % 'events', so what detail we want to hide from non-admin in new field 'details'. 

I think we can use the existing policy only. I read the Sean comment on spec about controlling the new filed for non-admin which can be controlled by exiting policy I think. Waiting for his confirmation.
If we pass the BASE_POLICY_NAME% 'events' policy authentication like microversion 2.62, then we will also show 'traceback' to non admin, which is not what we want.
yeah, that is what I was thinking about what is main difference between these two pieces of information. That is why I felt resuing existing policy is good enough here.

No, we also would like to get 500. For example, as a non-admin user, if I create a server failed because of NoValidHost(500), if I can get this message in details, that I can try again. For non-admin user, I think this is enough.
So we cannot only catch 4xx error code in 'details' field.

after having discussion on IRC, it seems we might need to filter or whitelist the exception which we want to add in 'details' field for non-admin. 

Currently, in case of non-nova exception, only exception names are included which can still leak the info about what driver are being used in cloud. and also not all nova exception are fixedable/debuggable by non-admin. Showing something which is not actionable or fixable by non-admin is of no use and might leaf cloud infra. 

May be we can add only 4xx or set of 4xx error in 'details' field ?

I think the reason for the policy was to signal to the deployer that there could be potential internal information leak if you enable this to the end user. Technically it is close to impossible to make an api that shows useful information in most of the cases and in the other hand free from any possible information leak.
My suggestion is to document that enabling 'details' to the end user could leak info. 

For me this is a trade off for the deployer:
a) she does not enable 'details' and she continue to handle tickets like "I tried to resize my instance but it failed, but I don't know why, please help" from the end user

b) she enables 'details' and get less tickets like above, but potentially leak some internal information like the type of the virtualization she uses.

For me if the deployer has a choice then I don't mind if one of those choices leaks information.

We don't want the traceback  or error name in the details field to be present in 2.62 at all. To have the details filed populated  with the fault.message you should use 2.83 so we shoudl be filtering out populating the details field also on the micro-version.

regarding reusing the policy below.
im not sure if we need to differenciate between the traceback details and the error name.

i think the exception name for nova exceptioans like we do for non nova exceptiosn would likely be the only useful info for a non admin to see. so having a policy to expose that alone i think is useful but i could see reusing this too.
it would not give us that granularity but it would be sufficent to adress the concern i had in the spec.

+1. also discussed with dan smith on IRC if exception name can be harmful and they are not so as long as we are hiding the error message.

this looks good to me. +1 on adding that in description.

Making the 'details' field visible to the non-admin user  helps to understand the nature of the problem (i.e. if the action can be retried) but in the other hand it might leak information about the deployment (e.g. the type of the hypervisor).

The implementation adds the globals before the unit elements list, which means this is useful *only* if you build fedora. DIB elements order doesn't matter as each element internally sets up run parts ordering for each build phase. Whether these come before or after on the command line shouldn't matter. I guess that means we could technically express this list as a set instead, but I'm not sure yaml can express a set?
The env vars are simpler to reason about.

nodepool/config.py.message: I'm not entirely certain how I feel about this yet. We now must keep __slots__ up-to-date with what is in __init__(), which is prone to error. As an example, 'build_timeout' is not present in __slots__, so mostly a -1 for that being missing for the time being.

After thinking about it some more, I think I'm ok with this, but not the missing attribute though. ;)  I don't suppose it's more trouble than forgetting to add a new attribute to the __eq__ method, which is what we deal with now.
nice catch, fixed
0: __slots__ is cool, but why not just check if __dict__ is equal here?

But there's nothing else to compare other than slots; the DiskImage can't have any attributes that aren't slots, so it can't have any private attributes.  If we wanted to set "_dib_cmd", we couldn't unless we added it to slots and then we would be comparing it in __eq__ (unless we filtered it out, which we could also do with __dict__).

Another option might be to have the ConfigValues construct themselves from a YAML dict, and store the raw YAML dict for comparison.

as in why didn't the original do that too? i don't know

my thinking at least was that comparing the slots is the external/configuration view of the diskimage so that's the only relevant parts of what might have changed in a comparison.
-1: This is going to be really long which will make logs harder to read.  It seems like just knowing the name of the diskimage is usually enough, is there a reason to add anything else?

We do seem to usually use diskimage.name in logs.  I could go either way on this, but I still think I would prefer __repr__ to be minimally useful info (ie, a demonstrated need in a log line), and if you want to temporarily dump the whole thing to debug something, why not do this there?  Or rename this to a new method just for that?

i found it useful to see what was being merged into the final image; it's not like a name 1:1 corresponds to a yaml config entry with inheritance any more; if you still feel -1 i can revert it to a name.

i'm also pretty sure it's never actually printed for now at least; so we could leave it (it's useful if you're actively debugging and put in your own print) and if it becomes too verbose, revert it then?
